Questions.correct_ans_explanation: The equation for gravitational force between two objects is proportional to the product of the two masses over the distance between the center of each object squared. If the radius were to increase by a factor of four, The distance between the center of masses of each object would also increase by a factor of four. As all the objects are made of iron at a constant density, the mass of each sphere would also increase, as mass = density ¬∑ volume. In this case the mass is proportional to r³ for a sphere, so mass would increase by 4³. So an increase by a factor of 4³ in each mass over an increase by a factor of 4² for the radius squared equates to 4³ ¬∑ 4³ / 4² = 256. The force would increase by a factor of 256, therefore the answer is D.
Questions.wrong_ans_explanation: The equation for gravitational force between two objects is proportional to the product of the two masses over the distance between the center of each object squared. If the radius were to increase by a factor of four, The distance between the center of masses of each object would also increase by a factor of four. As all the objects are made of iron at a constant density, the mass of each sphere would also increase, as mass = density ¬∑ volume. In this case the mass is proportional to r³ for a sphere, so mass would increase by 4³. So an increase by a factor of 4³ in each mass over an increase by a factor of 4² for the radius squared equates to 4³ ¬∑ 4³ / 4² = 256. The force would increase by a factor of 256, therefore the answer is D.
Questions.question: Two iron spheres each with radius R are placed in contact as shown. The gravitational force they exert on each other has magnitude F. If, instead, two iron spheres of radius 4R are placed in contact, then what is the magnitude of the gravitational force between the two spheres? Assume that all spheres are of the same density.
options:
F

 4F

 16F

 256F

Questions.correct_ans_explanation: Between R₁₀₀ and R₃₀₀, the equivalent resistance is 400Œ©. The voltage across these two resistors and the 200Œ© resistor must be the same because they are in parallel, and since Voltage = Current ¬∑ Resistance, we can see that the current across the R₂₀₀ resistor must be twice the current across the other two resistors. Power = Voltage ¬∑ Current, so the power output of R₂₀₀ is twice the combined power output of the other two resistors. R₃₀₀ and R₁₀₀, being in series, have equivalent current, meaning R₃₀₀ must have triple the power output of R₁₀₀. Energy U used by a capacitor is equal to Power over time, so U₂₀₀ > U₃₀₀ > U₁₀₀, hence the answer is C.
Questions.wrong_ans_explanation: Between R₁₀₀ and R₃₀₀, the equivalent resistance is 400Œ©. The voltage across these two resistors and the 200Œ© resistor must be the same because they are in parallel, and since Voltage = Current ¬∑ Resistance, we can see that the current across the R₂₀₀ resistor must be twice the current across the other two resistors. Power = Voltage ¬∑ Current, so the power output of R₂₀₀ is twice the combined power output of the other two resistors. R₃₀₀ and R₁₀₀, being in series, have equivalent current, meaning R₃₀₀ must have triple the power output of R₁₀₀. Energy U used by a capacitor is equal to Power over time, so U₂₀₀ > U₃₀₀ > U₁₀₀, hence the answer is C.
Questions.question: The circuit shown has resistors connected to a battery in a circuit. Over a given amount of time, which of the following correctly ranks the energy U used by the three resistors?
options:
U₃₀₀ > U₂₀₀ > U₁₀₀ 

 U₃₀₀ > U₁₀₀  > U₂₀₀ 

 U₂₀₀ > U₃₀₀ > U₁₀₀  

 U₂₀₀ > U₁₀₀  > U₃₀₀

Questions.correct_ans_explanation: A is wrong because dividing the distance (60 m) by the time (8 s) yields the average speed while braking. C is wrong because we do not need this equation to find velocity, although we could use it if we knew the acceleration. D is wrong for the same reason; not every equation defining velocity contains acceleration. This leaves B. At a constant acceleration, the average speed will be equal to the speed at halfway through braking at t = 4 s, which equals half of the starting speed. Doubling this average speed would then yield the initial speed, meaning the answer is B.
Questions.wrong_ans_explanation: A is wrong because dividing the distance (60 m) by the time (8 s) yields the average speed while braking. C is wrong because we do not need this equation to find velocity, although we could use it if we knew the acceleration. D is wrong for the same reason; not every equation defining velocity contains acceleration. This leaves B. At a constant acceleration, the average speed will be equal to the speed at halfway through braking at t = 4 s, which equals half of the starting speed. Doubling this average speed would then yield the initial speed, meaning the answer is B.
Questions.question: A car traveling at a certain speed suddenly applies the brakes, requiring 8 s to come to rest at a constant acceleration. The car comes to rest after 60 m. Can the speed of the car immediately before the brakes were applied be determined without first determining the car‚Äôs acceleration?
options:
Yes, by dividing the distance (60 m) by the time (8 s).

 Yes, by finding the average speed during braking and doubling it.

 No, because the acceleration must be known to use standard equations such as ‚àÜx = v₀t + ¬Ωat².


 No, because the fundamental relationship that defines velocity also contains acceleration.

Questions.correct_ans_explanation: B is incorrect because an acceleration perpendicular to the direction of motion would not change the speed of Jupiter. C is incorrect because there is no external torque on the system, meaning angular momentum must be conserved and cannot change. D is incorrect because a centripetal force greater than the gravitational force would not cause an increase in speed. This leaves A, which is correct because due to conservation of energy, energy is conserved, meaning as potential energy decreases as Jupiter gets closer to the sun, that energy becomes kinetic energy as Jupiter picks up speed.
Questions.wrong_ans_explanation: B is incorrect because an acceleration perpendicular to the direction of motion would not change the speed of Jupiter. C is incorrect because there is no external torque on the system, meaning angular momentum must be conserved and cannot change. D is incorrect because a centripetal force greater than the gravitational force would not cause an increase in speed. This leaves A, which is correct because due to conservation of energy, energy is conserved, meaning as potential energy decreases as Jupiter gets closer to the sun, that energy becomes kinetic energy as Jupiter picks up speed.
Questions.question: While orbiting the Sun in an elliptical orbit, Jupiter gains speed as it gets closer to the Sun. Which of the following best explains this increase in speed?
options:
As Jupiter gets closer to the Sun, the Jupiter-Sun system loses potential energy as Jupiter gains kinetic energy.

 A component of the gravitational force exerted on Jupiter is perpendicular to the direction of motion, causing an acceleration and therefore an increase in speed along that direction.


 The torque exerted on Jupiter by the Sun during this segment of the orbit leads to a gain in the Jupiter-Sun system‚Äôs angular momentum.


 The centripetal force Jupiter experiences is greater than the gravitational force it experiences during this section of the orbit, causing Jupiter to gain speed as it gets closer to the Sun.

Questions.correct_ans_explanation: From the acceleration graph, we can see that the marble is experiencing a nonzero, constant acceleration. We can also see that the velocity begins negative and ends up positive. The only scenario where we see the marble experiencing a constant acceleration beginning with a negative velocity and ending with a positive velocity is with C, so C is the correct answer.
Questions.wrong_ans_explanation: From the acceleration graph, we can see that the marble is experiencing a nonzero, constant acceleration. We can also see that the velocity begins negative and ends up positive. The only scenario where we see the marble experiencing a constant acceleration beginning with a negative velocity and ending with a positive velocity is with C, so C is the correct answer.
Questions.question: The graphs shown represent the position x, velocity v, and acceleration a as a function of time t for a ball moving along one dimension. Which of the following could describe the motion of the ball?
options:
Rolling on the floor and then bouncing off a wall

 Rolling down one side of a bowl and then up the other side

 Rolling up a ramp and then rolling back down


 Falling and then bouncing off of the floor

Questions.correct_ans_explanation: B is incorrect because a force perpendicular to the direction of motion would not lead to an increase in speed. C is incorrect because although energy stored in the fuel is converted, it is not converted into potential energy. C and D are incorrect because if the car is increasing in speed, then some of its acceleration must be in its direction of motion, but also because the car is travelling in a circular track, some of the car‚Äôs acceleration must be perpendicular to its direction of motion as centripetal acceleration. This leaves A, which is the correct answer, as the chemical potential energy stored in the fuel is converted into the car‚Äôs mechanical energy.
Questions.wrong_ans_explanation: B is incorrect because a force perpendicular to the direction of motion would not lead to an increase in speed. C is incorrect because although energy stored in the fuel is converted, it is not converted into potential energy. C and D are incorrect because if the car is increasing in speed, then some of its acceleration must be in its direction of motion, but also because the car is travelling in a circular track, some of the car‚Äôs acceleration must be perpendicular to its direction of motion as centripetal acceleration. This leaves A, which is the correct answer, as the chemical potential energy stored in the fuel is converted into the car‚Äôs mechanical energy.
Questions.question: A car going around an unbanked (flat) circular track increases its speed as it travels around the track. Which of the following can explain why the car‚Äôs speed increases?
options:
The chemical potential energy of the fuel is converted into mechanical energy.

 A component of the frictional force exerted on the tires by the ground is directed toward the center of the track.

 The car‚Äôs velocity and acceleration are parallel

 The car‚Äôs velocity and acceleration are perpendicular.

Questions.correct_ans_explanation: Tape III indicates that the distance between the marks increases as time elapses. Tapes II and IV show increases and decreases in the spacings between the marks meaning a non constant acceleration for each tape. Tape I indicates that speed is fairly constant with the marks being equidistant and therefore has no acceleration.

Tapes II and IV show increases and decreases in the spacings between the marks meaning a non constant acceleration for each tape. Tape I indicates that speed is fairly constant with the marks being equidistant and therefore has no acceleration.

I

 II

 III

Questions.correct_ans_explanation: To find velocity as a function of time, use the equation v = v₀ + at. If the final velocity equals twice the initial velocity, v = 2v₀. Solving for time gives t = 20 s.
Questions.wrong_ans_explanation: To find velocity as a function of time, use the equation v = v₀ + at. If the final velocity equals twice the initial velocity, v = 2v₀. Solving for time gives t = 20 s.
Questions.question: An object has an initial velocity of 20.0 m/s. If it accelerates at the constant rate of 1.0 m/s², at what time will its velocity equal twice its initial velocity?

The slopes of the other lines indicate that line D has the greatest acceleration (slope) followed by line C and then line B.
Questions.wrong_ans_explanation: The slope of the line of an object equals the acceleration of that object. Line A has zero slope, indicating  a constant velocity and therefore zero acceleration. The slopes of the other lines indicate that line D has the greatest acceleration (slope) followed by line C and then line B.

A > B > C > D

Questions.correct_ans_explanation: In the absence of air resistance, both objects reach the ground at the same time with the same speed because they are both in Earth‚Äôs gravitational field. This means the acceleration due to gravity for both objects is equal.
Questions.wrong_ans_explanation: In the absence of air resistance, both objects reach the ground at the same time with the same speed because they are both in Earth‚Äôs gravitational field. This means the acceleration due to gravity for both objects is equal.
Questions.question: A 25 kg object and a 50 kg object are dropped simultaneously from the same height above the ground. In the absence of air resistance, which of the following is true?
options:
The gravitational force acting on the 50 kg object is stronger so it reaches the ground first with a higher speed.

 The 25 kg object has a smaller inertia and is easier to accelerate so it reaches the ground first with a higher speed.

 Both objects are in the same gravitational field so they reach the ground with the same speed at the same time.

 The 25 kg object has a smaller inertia so it has a larger speed, but both objects reach the ground at the same time.

Questions.correct_ans_explanation: The boulder is within the gravitational field of the Earth, so the acceleration will point downwards. The horizontal component of the velocity remains constant because there is no air resistance, so there is no horizontal component of acceleration. At maximum height, the vertical component of the initial velocity is zero. The acceleration vector points downwards and the velocity vector points horizontally, perpendicular to the acceleration.
Questions.wrong_ans_explanation: The boulder is within the gravitational field of the Earth, so the acceleration will point downwards. The horizontal component of the velocity remains constant because there is no air resistance, so there is no horizontal component of acceleration. At maximum height, the vertical component of the initial velocity is zero. The acceleration vector points downwards and the velocity vector points horizontally, perpendicular to the acceleration.
Questions.question: A catapult launches a boulder at some velocity v at an angle Œ∏ above the horizontal. When the boulder is at the highest part of its trajectory, which of the following diagrams best depicts the boulder‚Äôs velocity and acceleration vectors? Assume no air resistance.

I

 II

 III

 IV

Questions.correct_ans_explanation: The ball is thrown with a horizontal velocity that remains constant due to no air resistance. The horizontal velocity and the mass can be ignored. The ball starts from rest in the vertical direction, so its time of flight is given by the equation y = ¬Ωat², which, plugging in the variables gives -40.0 m = ¬Ω(-9.80 m/s²)t², t = 2.86.
Questions.wrong_ans_explanation: The ball is thrown with a horizontal velocity that remains constant due to no air resistance. The horizontal velocity and the mass can be ignored. The ball starts from rest in the vertical direction, so its time of flight is given by the equation y = ¬Ωat², which, plugging in the variables gives -40.0 m = ¬Ω(-9.80 m/s²)t², t = 2.86.
Questions.question: A 2 kg ball is thrown horizontally from the roof of a building of height 40 m with a speed of 24.0 m/s. What is the approximate time the ball is in the air, assuming no air resistance?

Because momentum is directly proportional to velocity, |‚àÜp=m‚àÜv|, the ball‚Äôs momentum will also increase at a constant amount each second it falls.
Questions.wrong_ans_explanation: The ball accelerates at a constant rate, with its velocity increasing at a constant amount of 9.8 m/s every second. Because momentum is directly proportional to velocity, |‚àÜp=m‚àÜv|, the ball‚Äôs momentum will also increase at a constant amount each second it falls.

options:
Momentum for each meter through which it falls

 Speed for each meter through which it falls

 Momentum during each second it falls

Questions.correct_ans_explanation: When the block is on the dirt path, there is a frictional force directed horizontally, opposite the direction of motion. There are also forces of gravity and the normal force of the path on the block that must cancel each other out, as we know the block is not accelerating in the vertical direction. There is a net force in the horizontal direction because when the block moves on the dirt path with friction, it begins to slow down.
Questions.wrong_ans_explanation: When the block is on the dirt path, there is a frictional force directed horizontally, opposite the direction of motion. There are also forces of gravity and the normal force of the path on the block that must cancel each other out, as we know the block is not accelerating in the vertical direction. There is a net force in the horizontal direction because when the block moves on the dirt path with friction, it begins to slow down.
Questions.question: A wooden block with mass 20 kg slides along the ice, a frictionless surface, at 5 m/s. The block leaves the ice and moves onto a dirt path that has a coefficient of friction Œºₖ = 0.2. Which of the following free body diagrams best represents the block on the path?
options:
I

 II

 III

 IV

Questions.correct_ans_explanation: When the block leaves the ice and moves onto the dirt path, it experiences a net force of Fₙₑₜ = ma = Œºₖmg. This force over distance x does -Œºₖmgx work on the block, or m(v² - v₀²) / 2 = -Œºₖmgx. The negative work equals the change in the block‚Äôs kinetic energy. Plugging in the variables and solving for x, the distance traveled, gives x = 6.38 m.
Questions.wrong_ans_explanation: When the block leaves the ice and moves onto the dirt path, it experiences a net force of Fₙₑₜ = ma = Œºₖmg. This force over distance x does -Œºₖmgx work on the block, or m(v² - v₀²) / 2 = -Œºₖmgx. The negative work equals the change in the block‚Äôs kinetic energy. Plugging in the variables and solving for x, the distance traveled, gives x = 6.38 m.

Questions.wrong_ans_explanation: The object‚Äôs velocity increases as it falls, and because the gravitational force is in the same direction as its velocity during that time, both the kinetic energy and the momentum increase due to gravity.

options:
The only force acting on it is the force of gravity so its momentum stays constant.

 The force of gravity is an external force so only its momentum increases. 

 Work is done by the gravitational force so its kinetic energy increases but its momentum stays constant.

 The external force of gravity causes both its momentum and its kinetic energy to increase.

Because momentum is equal to mass times velocity, the momentum will point in the same direction as the velocity. Since the velocity is changing, the momentum is changing,

options:
constant because its speed is constant

 constant because the acceleration of the car is constant

 not constant because there is an external force acting on the car to change its direction

 not constant because there is no work done on the car by the external force

options:
It will decrease because a force is applied to the object opposite its initial velocity

 It will increase because the net force is in the direction of the initial velocity

 It will remain constant because the net force acting on the object is zero

 It's undetermined because the mass of the object is unknown.

Questions.correct_ans_explanation: The force due to friction on the box is mg¬∑cos(Œ∏)¬∑Œº = 4¬∑9.8¬∑cos(45¬∞)¬∑0.4 = 11.08 N. The work done will be negative because the cube travels against the frictional force. Multiplying the force (which is negative) by the distance traveled gives the work done; -11.08¬∑3 = -33.26 J.
Questions.wrong_ans_explanation: The force due to friction on the box is mg¬∑cos(Œ∏)¬∑Œº = 4¬∑9.8¬∑cos(45¬∞)¬∑0.4 = 11.08 N. The work done will be negative because the cube travels against the frictional force. Multiplying the force (which is negative) by the distance traveled gives the work done; -11.08¬∑3 = -33.26 J.
Questions.question: A 4 kg cube is held in place at the top of a ramp inclined at 45¬∞ and then released. It travels down the ramp which is 3 m long. What is the work done by the frictional force on the cube as it slides all the way down the incline if the coefficient of kinetic friction between the cube and the ramp is 0.4?

Questions.correct_ans_explanation: Potential energy of a spring is given by the equation ¬Ωkx². In this case, the total energy and the starting potential energy equal, from the equation, 0.28 J. The location where all the energy is in the form kinetic energy will also be where the spring is at its maximum velocity. The equation for kinetic energy is ¬Ωmv², so setting that equal to 0.28 (the total energy) and solving for velocity gives 1.06 m/s. Because all the energy is kinetic energy, there must be no kinetic energy, so it will be at x = 0 m. The only answer that fits this is D.
Questions.wrong_ans_explanation: Potential energy of a spring is given by the equation ¬Ωkx². In this case, the total energy and the starting potential energy equal, from the equation, 0.28 J. The location where all the energy is in the form kinetic energy will also be where the spring is at its maximum velocity. The equation for kinetic energy is ¬Ωmv², so setting that equal to 0.28 (the total energy) and solving for velocity gives 1.06 m/s. Because all the energy is kinetic energy, there must be no kinetic energy, so it will be at x = 0 m. The only answer that fits this is D.
Questions.question: A 0.5 kg block is glued to a horizontal, ideal spring with spring constant k = 225 N¬∑m on a flat, frictionless surface. The spring is stretched 0.05 m out then released. Where does the maximum speed of the block occur and what does it equal?
options:
1.125 m/s at ¬± A 

 1.125 m/s at x = 0 

 1.06 m/s at ¬± A

This is incorrect because, relative to the desk, the object is not 2 m above the level of the floor, only 0 m above the level of the desk. This leaves A, which only includes the object‚Äôs kinetic energy.

options:
only kinetic energy as it slides on the frictionless surface

 only gravitational potential energy since the table is 2 m above the floor

 the sum of the kinetic and the gravitational potential energy since the surface is frictionless


 the difference between the kinetic energy and the gravitational potential energy

Questions.correct_ans_explanation: The initial energy of the body is ¬Ωmv² + mgh. Due to conservation of energy, the energy in the system remains constant at whatever point during the object‚Äôs fall.  So calculating ¬Ωmv² + mgh will give the correct answer of 60.3 J.
Questions.wrong_ans_explanation: The initial energy of the body is ¬Ωmv² + mgh. Due to conservation of energy, the energy in the system remains constant at whatever point during the object‚Äôs fall.  So calculating ¬Ωmv² + mgh will give the correct answer of 60.3 J.
Questions.question: A 3 kg object with a speed of 1 m/s slides off a frictionless horizontal desk that is 2 m above the floor. What is the energy of the object halfway through its fall off the desk?

Questions.wrong_ans_explanation: A full oscillation goes from x = A to x = -A and back to x = A. From this, we can see that the body travels a distance of 4A, so the answer is A.

4A

 2A

 A / 2

Questions.correct_ans_explanation: As the frictional force is applied opposite to the direction of motion, it does negative work on the block. This means a negative change in the kinetic energy of the block, so the answer is B.
Questions.wrong_ans_explanation: As the frictional force is applied opposite to the direction of motion, it does negative work on the block. This means a negative change in the kinetic energy of the block, so the answer is B.
Questions.question: A slab of ice sliding across an ice rink at 25 m/s enters a region of rough ice where a frictional force of 0.6 N acts. What will happen to the kinetic energy of the slab when it enters the rough section?
options:
It will increase because the force is applied in the same direction as the velocity of the block.

 It will decrease because the force is applied in the opposite direction as the velocity of the block.

 It will not change since it is still sliding on ice at 25 m/s.

 It cannot be determined with the information given.

Questions.correct_ans_explanation: From the equation F = ma = GMm / R² ‚Üí a = g = GM / R², the gravitational acceleration on the planet is gₑ / gₚ = (Mₑ / Rₑ²) / (3Mₑ / (2Rₑ)²) = 4 / 3. So if the acceleration on the planet is 3gₑ / 4 = gₚ, then the period is Tₚ = 2ùúã‚àö((2 m) / (7.35 m/s²)) = 3.28 s.
Questions.wrong_ans_explanation: From the equation F = ma = GMm / R² ‚Üí a = g = GM / R², the gravitational acceleration on the planet is gₑ / gₚ = (Mₑ / Rₑ²) / (3Mₑ / (2Rₑ)²) = 4 / 3. So if the acceleration on the planet is 3gₑ / 4 = gₚ, then the period is Tₚ = 2ùúã‚àö((2 m) / (7.35 m/s²)) = 3.28 s.
Questions.question: The period of a simple pendulum 2 m long at the surface of the Earth is 2.84 s. What is its period if it is taken to a planet whose mass is 3M, and radius is 2R?

Questions.correct_ans_explanation: The gravitational force between the masses is an attractive force, meaning the net force on m₃ is toward the left. Its magnitude is calculated by F₁₃ + F₂₃ = Fₙₑₜ. From the formula F = GM₁M₂ / r², F₁₃ = 8.75 ¬∑ 10⁻⁷ N to the left. F₂₃ = 5.84 ¬∑ 10⁻⁶ N to the left. So Fₙₑₜ = 6.7 ¬∑ 10⁻⁶ N to the left.
Questions.wrong_ans_explanation: The gravitational force between the masses is an attractive force, meaning the net force on m₃ is toward the left. Its magnitude is calculated by F₁₃ + F₂₃ = Fₙₑₜ. From the formula F = GM₁M₂ / r², F₁₃ = 8.75 ¬∑ 10⁻⁷ N to the left. F₂₃ = 5.84 ¬∑ 10⁻⁶ N to the left. So Fₙₑₜ = 6.7 ¬∑ 10⁻⁶ N to the left.

Questions.correct_ans_explanation: The observer‚Äôs perceived shift in frequency happens because of the relative motion between the stationary observer and the moving car. The sonic wave fronts crowd together as waves produced by the car approach waves that were previously created. As the wavelength appears to decrease, the frequency appears to increase.
Questions.wrong_ans_explanation: The observer‚Äôs perceived shift in frequency happens because of the relative motion between the stationary observer and the moving car. The sonic wave fronts crowd together as waves produced by the car approach waves that were previously created. As the wavelength appears to decrease, the frequency appears to increase.

a lower frequency because the wavelength between successive waves is shorter as the car approaches the stationary observer with a velocity relative to the observer.

 a higher frequency because the wavelength between successive waves is shorter as the car approaches the stationary observer with a velocity relative to the observer.

 no change in frequency since the observer is stationary relative to the car.

Questions.correct_ans_explanation: The change in momentum of one gas particle is the change in velocity times the mass. The velocity perpendicular to the surface is v¬∑cos(30¬∞) or v / 2. This value times 2 is the change in velocity of the particle, as the particle bounces back elastically. To find the change in momentum of one gas particle we multiply this by m. Then to find the total change in momentum of all the gas particles, we multiply this by n to get nmv, choice A.
Questions.wrong_ans_explanation: The change in momentum of one gas particle is the change in velocity times the mass. The velocity perpendicular to the surface is v¬∑cos(30¬∞) or v / 2. This value times 2 is the change in velocity of the particle, as the particle bounces back elastically. To find the change in momentum of one gas particle we multiply this by m. Then to find the total change in momentum of all the gas particles, we multiply this by n to get nmv, choice A.

 Because no torque was applied to her, neither her kinetic energy nor her angular momentum increased.

Questions.correct_ans_explanation: A node is a point on a standing wave that is fixed in position. An antinode is the opposite; it is a point that gets displaced the farthest on a standing wave. The waveform shows the same wave 180¬∞ out of phase with itself. The points that stay in the same position despite the phase shift are nodes and the points that are farthest away from their previous position are antinodes.

The waveform shows the same wave 180¬∞ out of phase with itself. Questions.correct_ans_explanation: Conservation of angular momentum states that if the system‚Äôs moment of inertia increases, then its angular velocity must decrease. The block falling on and sticking to the disk adds to the system‚Äôs moment of inertia, causing it to increase from l₀ to l₀ + Iₓ. The angular velocity must therefore decrease.
Questions.wrong_ans_explanation: Conservation of angular momentum states that if the system‚Äôs moment of inertia increases, then its angular velocity must decrease. The block falling on and sticking to the disk adds to the system‚Äôs moment of inertia, causing it to increase from l₀ to l₀ + Iₓ. The angular velocity must therefore decrease.
Questions.question: A flat disk with a moment of inertia I₀ is rotating with an angular velocity œâ₀ when a small block with rotational inertia Iₓ drops vertically on the edge of the disk and stays there. What will happen to the angular velocity of the system?
options:
It will increase because the block falling has exerted a torque on the disk in the same direction of the disk‚Äôs angular velocity.

 It will decrease because the block exerted a frictional force on the disk opposing the disk‚Äôs angular velocity.

 It will decrease because system‚Äôs moment of inertia increased from l₀ to l₀ + Iₓ

 It will won‚Äôt change because no net torque was applied to the disk when the block dropped vertically on the disk

Questions.correct_ans_explanation: The equivalent resistance of the circuit is 35Œ©. With a 12V battery, this means the current in R₁ is 12/35. Because R₂ and R₃ are in parallel, they must have the same voltage, meaning I₂R₂ = I₃R₃. I₂ + I₃ = 12/35 because of Kirchoff‚Äôs junction rule. Solving for I₃ gives 0.11 A, so A is the correct answer.
Questions.wrong_ans_explanation: The equivalent resistance of the circuit is 35Œ©. With a 12V battery, this means the current in R₁ is 12/35. Because R₂ and R₃ are in parallel, they must have the same voltage, meaning I₂R₂ = I₃R₃. I₂ + I₃ = 12/35 because of Kirchoff‚Äôs junction rule. Solving for I₃ gives 0.11 A, so A is the correct answer.

They are subtracted from one another because they are directed in opposite directions. This multiplied by 25 s equals 20  N¬∑m¬∑s, so B is the correct answer.

Questions.correct_ans_explanation: Refer to the top parallel wire as wire 1 and the bottom parallel wire as wire 2. The equivalent resistance is 50Œ©, meaning I₁₀ = 0.4 A, and V₁₀ = 4 V. Because R₅₀ and R₇₀ are in parallel with R₆₀, the voltages across each parallel wire must be equal. I₁(R₅₀ + R₇₀) = I₂R₂₀. Because of Kirchoff‚Äôs junction rule, I₁ + I₂ = I₁. Solving for both currents, this gives I₁ = 0.133 A and I₂ = 0.267. V₅₀ = I₁R₅₀, V₇₀ = I₁R₇₀, and V₆₀ = I₂R₆₀. Solving for each of the voltages and comparing them gives V₆₀ > V₇₀ > V₅₀ > V₁₀, so D is the correct answer.
Questions.wrong_ans_explanation: Refer to the top parallel wire as wire 1 and the bottom parallel wire as wire 2. The equivalent resistance is 50Œ©, meaning I₁₀ = 0.4 A, and V₁₀ = 4 V. Because R₅₀ and R₇₀ are in parallel with R₆₀, the voltages across each parallel wire must be equal. I₁(R₅₀ + R₇₀) = I₂R₂₀. Because of Kirchoff‚Äôs junction rule, I₁ + I₂ = I₁. Solving for both currents, this gives I₁ = 0.133 A and I₂ = 0.267. V₅₀ = I₁R₅₀, V₇₀ = I₁R₇₀, and V₆₀ = I₂R₆₀. Solving for each of the voltages and comparing them gives V₆₀ > V₇₀ > V₅₀ > V₁₀, so D is the correct answer.
